section.title: Negative Exponents x^{-n}
section.p: A positive integer exponent indicates repeated multiplication. For instance, 2^4 = \underbrace{2\cdot 2\cdot 2\cdot 2}_{\text{4 factors of 2}} = 16.

statement.p: Suppose n = 1,2,3,4,\ldots is a positive integer. We define a^n = \underbrace{a \cdot a \cdot \cdot \cdots \cdot a}_{\text{$n$ factors of $a$}}. In particular, a^1 = a.

section.p: When multiplying powers with the same base, you should add the exponents. For example, 2^3 \cdot 2^4 = \underbrace{2\cdot 2\cdot 2}_{\text{3 factors}} \cdot \underbrace{2\cdot 2\cdot 2\cdot 2}_{\text{4 factors}} = 2^{3+4} = 2^7.

What would happen if one of the exponents was zero? For example, according to our law of exponents above, 2^0\cdot 2^4 = 2^{0+4} = 2^4. So that multiplying by 2^0 didn't change the other factor; it's as if we were multiplying by one! In fact, we will define 2^0 = 1.

statement.p: Suppose a\neq 0 is a non-zero real number. We define a^0 = 1. Note that we leave undefined the expression 0^0.

section.p: When dividing powers of the same base, you should subtract the exponents. For example, \frac{2^6}{2^2} = \frac{2\cdot 2\cdot 2\cdot 2\cdot 2\cdot 2}{2\cdot 2} = 2^{6-2} =2^4.

statement.p: Suppose a\neq 0 is a non-zero real number. Then \frac{a^n}{a^m} = a^{n-m}.

section.p:
What would happen if one of the exponents was negative? It should be consistent with the above laws of exponents. Consider,
2^{-1} \cdot 2^3 = 2^{-1+3} = 2^{2}. Observe that multiplying by 2^{-1} had the effect of cutting 2^3 in half. This suggests that 2^{-1} is the same as the reciprocal of two, that is 2^{-1} = \frac{1}{2}. In general, we define the opposite exponent to mean the reciprocal.

statement.p: Suppose a\neq 0 is a non-zero real number. We define a^{-n} = \frac{1}{a^n}

ol.li: Apply the exponent before multiplying by -1 -2^4 = - 16.

This is an even power of a negative number
(-2)^4 = (-2)(-2)(-2)(-2) = + 16 = 16.

A negative exponent is equivalent to the reciprocal
2^{-4} = \frac{1}{2^4} = \frac{1}{16}.

This applies for a power in the denominator as well
\frac{1}{2^{-4}} = 2^4 = 16.

Apply the exponent before multiplying by -1 or dividing
\frac{1}{-2^{4}} = \frac{1}{-16} = - \frac{1}{16}.

section.title: Scientific Notation
section.p:
A number in the form a \times 10^n with 1 \leq |a| \lt 10 is said to be in scientific notation. For example,
4.25 \times 10^{7} = 42500000, \quad -9\times 10^{-4} = -0.0009 are both in scientific notation. We can use properties of exponents to conveniently multiple and divide.

section.title: Rational Exponents x^{m/n}
section.p: When taking a power of a power, you should multiply the exponents. For example, \left(2^2\right)^3 = 2^2\cdot 2^2\cdot 2^2 = 2^{3\cdot 2}=2^6. This is the same as \left(2^3\right)^2 = 2^3\cdot 2^3 = 2^{2\cdot 3}=2^6.

What happens when we apply this law to an exponent that is a fraction like 1/2? Consider, \left(2^{1/2}\right)^{2} = 2^{(1/2)\cdot 2} = 2^1 = 2. Observe that 2^{1/2} is a number whose square is 2, just like \sqrt{2}. In fact, we define 2^{1/2}=\sqrt{2}. In general, we define the reciprocal exponent as a principal n-th root.

statement.p: For positive integer n, we define a^{1/n} = \sqrt[n]{a}. We also assume a\geq 0 in the case that n is even.

example.p: The cube root of 8 in exponential notation is 8^{1/3} = \sqrt[3]{8} = 2. The cube root of -8 is (-8)^{1/3} = \sqrt[3]{-8} = -2.

section.p: Recall that a rational number is a ratio of integers m/n, where n\neq 0. We can now make sense of expressions with rational exponents.

example.p: To illustrate, 4^{3/2} = (4^{1/2})^3 = (\sqrt{4})^3 = 2^3 = 8. Alternatively, 4^{3/2} = (4^3)^{1/2} = \sqrt{4^3} = \sqrt{64} = 8. Notice both ways give the same result.

solution.p:
First, observe that 8^2 = 64 and 4^3 = 64.
Order of operations requires us to perform the exponent before multiplying by -1 -64^{3/2} = - \left(\sqrt{64}\right)^3 = - 8^3 = -512.
Recall the negative exponents means reciprocal
64^{-3/2} = \frac{1}{64^{3/2}} = \frac{1}{\left(\sqrt{64}\right)^3} = \frac{1}{8^3} = \frac{1}{512}
Order of operations requires us to perform the operations inside parenthesis before the exponent.
(-64)^{2/3} = \left(\sqrt[3]{-64}\right)^2 = \left(-4\right)^2 = 16
The exponent is performed before the division.
\frac{1}{{64}^{-2/3}} = 64^{2/3} = \left(\sqrt[3]{64}\right)^2 = \left(4\right)^2 = 16

section.title: Laws of Exponents
section.p: Here's a summary of the Laws of Exponents encountered in this chapter.

row.cell: Power of Product: (a b)^n = a^{n} b^n
Product of Powers: a^m a^n = a^{m+n}
